I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been active in supporting trade and trade 
facilitation in its developing member countries (DMCs) through public sector and private sector 
operations. Providing assistance to promote trade-related capacity development in developing 
countries is an integral part of promoting the future economic development and prosperity of 
ADB's DMCs. The design and monitoring framework sets out how the proposed technical 
assistance (TA) will advance ADB’s efforts to help DMCs integrate more fully into the world 
trading system (Appendix 1).1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Trade is a highly effective tool to help developing countries boost economic growth and 
generate the resources necessary to reduce poverty. Trade (i) enhances a country's access to 
goods, services, technologies, and knowledge; (ii) stimulates the entrepreneurial activities of the 
private sector; (iii) creates jobs and attracts private capital; (iv) fosters vital learning processes; 
and (v) increases foreign exchange earnings.     
 
3.  In ADB's experience, some DMCs lack capacity to harness maximum benefits from 
international trade. Constraints to trade can be broadly categorized as relating to (i) trade policy 
and regulation; (ii) poor physical infrastructure; and (iii) trade development issues, including 
access to trade finance and technology gaps. 
 
4.  An ADB study released in March 2013 identified a trade finance gap of $425 billion in 
developing Asia.2 The survey-based study also revealed that access to more trade finance 
could create 2% more production and result in 2% more jobs. Increasing access to trade finance 
is important to economic growth and job creation. 
 
5.  A key cause of lack of development of trade finance is because many banks in DMCs 
struggle to establish and/or maintain correspondent banking relationships with international 
banks, which are needed to access liquidity and guarantees in support of trade. While some 
factors (e.g., political and macroeconomic instability) are beyond their control, banks in DMCs 
often lack financial and technical capacities, which inhibit potential international correspondent 
banks from establishing credit lines to support trade. As a result, less financial support is 
available for companies in DMCs engaged in importing and exporting of goods and services. 
This reduces the availability and increases the cost of trade finance in many least developed 
countries, hindering their full participation in international trade. 
 
6.  ADB has previously supported development of trade finance through two TA projects, 
whose implementation started in 2009 and 2013.3 The consultants engaged under these two 
projects successfully conducted in-depth credit analysis on over 100 banks in DMCs which 
enabled ADB to establish credit limits on banks that underpinned the exponential growth of the 
TFP and its related development impact and mobilization of most of ADB’s commercial co-
financing. Under these projects, knowledge sharing seminars were also conducted in Armenia, 
Azerbaijan, Mongolia, Myanmar, Nepal, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan. Currently, ADB’s Trade 
Finance Program (TFP) involves over 125 international banks and 100 banks in DMCs. These

Timor Leste, Fiji, Papua New Guinea, and Samoa, due to lack of budget and human resources.    
   
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
7.  The proposed TA is linked closely to the operations of the TFP, and is designed to 
complement the TFP’s development impact, operations, and expansion.  The proposed TA will 
build on the ongoing work under the TA projects started in 2009 and 2013 by  assessing 
capacity constraints in banks and banking systems in DMCs, by analyzing banks and their 
capacity to participate in the TFP, either for the first time or on an ongoing basis through annual 
reviews and by providing training to banks to improve their capacity to provide trade finance to 
companies, including many SMEs. The proposed TA will continue to benefit current partner 
banks in TFP in the form of monitoring and knowledge sharing. The proposed TA will benefit 
new banks in the new markets TFP plans to expand into in 2014 and beyond through monitoring 
and trade finance capacity building for these banks. 
 
8.  The TA supports and is complementary to ADB's public operations in trade and trade 
facilitation projects.  It is linked to the Financial Sector Operational Plan as well as a number of 
the  strategies  and  business  opportunities  presented  in  country  strategy  papers,  regional 
cooperation strategy and programs, and country operations business plans for ADB's DMCs.  A 
review of these documents underscores the importance of trade finance capacity development 
in DMCs to enable ADB to meet its development objectives. An overview of some of the specific 
country and regional strategies and business plans with direct links to the TA is provided in a 
supplementary appendix.  
   
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact of the TA will be higher levels of intraregional trade and higher levels of trade 
between DMCs. The outcome of the TA will be enhanced trade finance capacity in DMCs.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA  outputs  and key  activities  are  linked to the  operation  and  potential further 
expansion of the TFP. This TA will also benefit new banks in the TFP’s target countries, which 
include Fiji, Papua New Guinea, Samoa, Timor-Leste, and Vanuatu.4 The TA will have the 
following outputs. 
 
1.  Knowledge Building in Developing Member Countries   
 
a.  Bank Assessments and Capacity Building   
 
11.  The  TA  will  conduct  approximately  10  new  bank  assessments  and  over  80  bank 
monitoring assessments from March 2014 to February 2015, enabling ADB to undertake due 
diligence on banks to identify and characterize any gaps in the financial and technical capacity 
                                                
4  Target countries may change depending on market demand and conditions.

4   
2.  Partnership Development 
 
16.  ADB will approve TFP credit lines to DMC banks following financial analysis and due 
diligence. These credit lines will continue to provide international banks with guarantees that will 
leverage existing available limits between international banks and banks in DMCs to support 
trade.  The  capacity  assessments  undertaken  by  the  TA  will  underpin  the  formation  and 
maintenance of partnerships between DMC and international banks. 
 
17.  Similarly, as the TFP guarantees and funds trade transactions (through banks) between 
importers and exporters, the work financed through the TA will foster partnerships between 
importing and exporting companies.  
 
18.  The TFP attracts approximately $2 billion in cofinancing every year. Bank monitoring 
assessments from the previous TA projects have been shared with major cofinancing partners 
(e.g., insurers and export credit agencies) (footnote 3).  As such, these previous TA projects 
have been important to attract cofinancing and private sector investment to DMCs to support 
trade. 
 
19.  The TFP expansion plans cover a multiyear period. Table 1 provides a summary of the 
assessments  and  seminars  delivered  for  2009–2013  under  the  previous  TA  projects  and 
expected deliverables in 2014–2015 under this proposed TA.

C.  Cost and Financing 
20.  The TA is estimated to cost $3 million, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-V). The funds will cover remuneration, travel, and per 
diem  for  international  consultants;  conference-related  expenditures;  and  miscellaneous 
expenses. A detailed cost breakdown and proposed financing plan are presented in Appendix 2. 
   
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
21.  The  TA  will  require  about  132  person-months  of  consulting  inputs.  Recruitment  of 
consultants will be in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as 
amended from time to time). ADB will engage a firm specializing in financial analysis and due 
diligence for emerging market banks, using quality and cost-based selection. In addition to 
conducting due diligence, drafting credit applications, monitoring risk, and administering the 
program, consultants and resource persons may be engaged by ADB to conduct seminars or

5 
training.  Terms  of  reference  for  the  consultants  are  provided  in  Appendix 3.  Equipment 
(smartphones) will be procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2013, as 
amended from time to time) and will be retained by ADB following TA completion. 
 
22.  ADB will be the executing agency while the Private Sector Operations Department will 
administer and implement the TA. Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with 
ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
The TA will be implemented from March 2014 to February 2015. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION  
23.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $3,000,000 on a grant basis for Capacity Development for 
Banks in Developing Member Countries under the Trade Finance Program.

9   Appendix 3 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  A reputable consultancy firm will be hired to undertake technical assistance (TA) in the 
form of financial analysis, including annual reviews, of approximately 100 banks every year in  
emerging Asian countries, including Afghanistan, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, 
Cambodia, Georgia, Indonesia, Kazakhstan, the Kyrgyz Republic, Mongolia, Myanmar, Nepal, 
Pakistan, the Philippines, Sri Lanka, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, and Viet Nam. 
 
2.  This work will be part of Asian Development Bank’s (ADB’s) Trade Finance Program 
(TFP). TFP fills private sector market gaps for trade finance by providing guarantees and loans 
through banks in the most challenging Asian markets, where gaps are proportionally largest. 
Just  within  2012, TFP supported  $4  billion  in  trade  through  over  2,000  transactions. TFP 
assumes risk on banks to support trade, hence its ongoing analysis, supported by this TA, and 
engagement with obligor banks is critical to operations. TFP has never had a default or a loss.1  
 
A.  Objective and/or Purpose of Assignment  
 
3.   The TA will support ADB’s TFP in assessing its risk on obligor banks on an ongoing 
basis while increasing the capacity of developing member countries (DMCs) of the ADB to 
attract and retain trade finance credit lines from the private sector. This is achieved primarily 
through financial analysis and due diligence of DMC banks. The TA will also deliver a few 
seminars  in-country  to  disseminate  information  about  what  has  been  learned  through  the 
analysis and due diligence process. This information will be valuable for DMC banks and 
regulators to seek improvements in their banking sector which will, among other benefits, help 
to attract more trade finance lines from TFP and international banks and investors. 
 
4.   This assignment is designed to (i) conduct financial analysis and due diligence on 
potential  partner  banks  in  the  TFP  and  annual  reviews  of  existing  TFP  partner  banks  to 
determine if DMC banks are suitable for (ongoing) participation in the TFP; (ii) identify capacity 
gaps that impede DMC banks from maintaining and accessing trade finance credit lines from 
ADB and international banks and/or investors; (iii) through the lead consultant, coordinate field 
work with the TFP to ensure that all required banks and countries are visited and analyzed 
within specified annual review periods; and (iv) conduct knowledge-sharing seminars to wider 
audiences in DMCs. 
 
B.  Required Inputs 
 
1.  Team  Leader  (international  bank  financial  analysis  expert,  12  person-
months) 
 
5.  Scope of work. The team leader will oversee all activities of the bank financial analysis 
experts and manage scheduling and general coordination with ADB’s TFP team. The consultant 
will (i) act as ADB's primary point of contact with the bank financial analysis experts; (ii) provide 
quality control and coherence to the work being conducted by the bank financial analysis 
experts; (iii)  perform  additional  functions  similar  to  the financial  analysis  experts;  and, (iv) 
coordinate with the TFP team regarding the technical assessment of trade finance operations, 
capacity building, and seminars on trade finance.

11.  Qualifications of the bank financial analysis experts include: 
 
(i)  master’s degree, or equivalent, in business administration, finance, economics, 
or related field; 
(ii)  at least 5 years of relevant work experience; 
(iii)  at  least  2  years  of  experience  in  bank  credit  or  financial  analysis  (specific 
experience in drafting credit or financial analysis reports and knowledge of risk 
ratings are an advantage); 
(iv)  strong knowledge of financial institutions, risk assessments, and country risk 
analysis; 
(v)  experience working in and/or with financial institutions; 
(vi)  experience in financial analysis and due diligence on banks;  
(vii)  excellent oral and written communication skills in English; and 
(viii)  willingness to travel extensively.  
 
3.  Trade Finance Expert (international, 12 person-months) 
 
12.  Scope of work. The trade finance expert, who may be engaged independent of any 
contract, will be responsible for (i) conducting technical assessments of trade finance operations 
for  DMC  banks  with  new  or  small  trade  finance  operations;  (ii)  proposing  measures  for 
improving trade finance operations; (iii) providing in-house training to bank staff involved in trade 
finance; (iv) conducting knowledge dissemination and/or training seminars aimed at a wider 
audience; and (v) conducting due diligence on DMC bank trade finance operations as required.  
 
13.  The tasks of the expert include: 
 
(i)  conduct  technical  assessments  of  trade  finance  operations  to  identify  gaps, 
weaknesses, and key risk areas for selected banks; 
(ii)  propose concrete measures to fill the gaps and mitigate risks identified by the 
technical assessment, including recommendations for improvements in systems, 
operations procedures, and risk management; 
(iii)  provide customized in-house training to selected DMC bank staff involved in 
trade finance operations; 
(iv)  conduct  trade  finance  due  diligence,  including  documentation  checks  and/or 
audits, and possibly visits to beneficiary companies; 
(v)  conduct knowledge  dissemination  and/or training  seminars  aimed  at  a  wider 
audience, which could cover the following topics: (a) key concepts and processes 
in trade finance, (b) benefits to banks from trade finance services, (c) essentials 
to develop and market trade finance products and services, (d) payment and risk
